Chapter 1: Questions on Wisdom
Thus have I heard:

Once, the Buddha was dwelling in a lofty seat of the TathÄgata's pure treasures, established by the TathÄgata, adorned with accumulated boundless virtues, the Buddha's wisdom and karmic retribution of the place where he practiced, removing what was practiced and ascending to the palace of the bodhisattvas, expounding countless praises of the TathÄgata, manifesting majestic transformations and guiding without obstruction, universally entering all, the mind dwelling on the subtle, guiding and advancing skillful practices, and equaling the wisdom of the past.

In future eons, he will greatly and ultimately have immeasurable virtue, in accord with perfect enlightenment, skillfully turning the Dharma wheel, with boundless wisdom discerning the truths, attaining mastery over all dharmas, seeing the faculties of all beings' minds, crossing to the other shore, understanding skillful means, eliminating all attachments and deviant karmic actions, and performing Buddha-works, all with sincere faith and transforming to attain tranquility.
Together with six million great bhiká¹£us, their minds are harmonious, having eliminated obstructions and the desires of the dusts and labors, and they are the sons of the Dharma King TathÄgata.

Cultivating the profound and wondrous Dharma, they give rise to the transformation of the Way, without error, their dignified deportment shining brightly, accomplishing the holy path and being the great benefactors of the assembly, the TathÄgata peacefully attaining excellent completion.

He was also together with a great assembly of bodhisattvas, immeasurable, limitless, inconceivable, a vast and great assembly whose activities were unobstructed. The bodhisattvas were able to transcend immeasurable buddha lands in an instant, and then expediently make offerings and serve the tathÄgatas of the ten directions, consult with them, listen to and accept the sÅ«tras without becoming weary.

They were always diligently encouraging sentient beings to transform, with skillful wisdom surpassing to reach the other shore and attain liberation, and establishing the unobstructed liberation gate. They were then able to transcend all the nets of thoughts and expectations of rewards, and approach the wisdom of omniscience and spiritual powers.
Their names were:

Mingtian Bodhisattva, Xuan youbu Bodhisattva, Zexian dou Bodhisattva, Zhaomingzang Bodhisattva, Juanmanyi Bodhisattva, Yongbu Bodhisattva, Yan guan Bodhisattva, Leiyin Bodhisattva, Liming Bodhisattva, and other such bodhisattvas, their number immeasurable, boundless, and beyond analogy.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised the path of the bodhisattvas' birth in the field of blessings, and the Dharma was called the teaching of no obstruction.

It is the pure path of all bodhisattvas, the power and fearlessness of the buddhas' Dharma, the perfect accomplishment of the affairs of holy wisdom, the attainment of freedom in the Dharma canon through the gate of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, the encounter with the Dharma seals that one enters, the resolution of the Dharma gates of the masses, the ultimate holy penetration that transcends and enters into wisdom, the irreversible wheel that is said to be non-retrogressive, and the equality of all vehicles that guides without duality.
It is the unimpeded wandering in the single category of the Dharma realm, and the differentiated explanation of the faculties of sentient beings' minds.

The wisdom he has entered is solitary and powerful, decisively understanding all dharmas, eliminating all the realms of mÄras, already transcending all afflictions in accordance with the Dharma, transforming the various dusts and false views, entering limitless wisdom and skillfully encouraging, practicing boundless praise and skillful means, proclaimed together by the buddhas of the ten directions, reaching the door of no-hope practice, no obstruction, and no location, circulating and flourishing all dharmas, decisively understanding in accordance with the response and universally entering, understanding with and without thought, playing in the profound and wonderful dependent origination, manifesting the boundless virtuous wisdom of the way, and adorning the body, speech, and mind of the Buddha.

In these three matters, the mind's activities return to wisdom that is inexhaustible, transcending the noble truths and destroying the Å›rÄvaka vehicle. With a tranquil body and mind, one expounds the teachings of the wise and teaches the pratyekabuddhas, leading them to attain the various spiritual powers. Guiding the MahÄyÄna, one enters the factors of the path and attains faith and acceptance in all dharmas. One proclaims the virtues that arise from the TathÄgata and expounds, analyzes, recites, and manifests the teachings. Wisdom instructs and reveals them, spreading them everywhere without exception.
At that time, the World-Honored One expounded this Dharma treatise of good wisdom, proclaiming and widely reciting it.
At that time, in the assembly there was a woman named Jewel Girl. She immediately rose from her seat, holding a wonderful pearl necklace in her right hand, and said to the World-Honored One:
Yes, Great Sage!

As I have said, my words are sincere and not false. If in this assembly the Buddha speaks the Dharma and the great beings expound it, I am able to fully uphold this sutra and spread it far and wide in the ten directions, encouraging countless people to establish the unsurpassed true path of the Dharma treasure.
If my vow is not changed, may the Tathagata's majestic spiritual power cause this jeweled thread to manifest the holy intention.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in response to the assembly, manifested a transformation, causing all the bodhisattvas to transform into pavilions and jeweled canopies above them:
These righteous ones!

Later, when you attain perfect enlightenment, if your buddha land is as subtle and pure as described, may the enlightenment tree of the Buddha's path manifest such auspicious signs as these jeweled pavilions and canopies, causing those in the assembly to see its purity and all be delighted.

At that time, the precious girl went before the Buddha and scattered pearl necklaces. After scattering the pearl necklaces, by the Buddha's majestic spiritual power and the precious girl's sincere vow and great resolve, they transformed into a pavilion in the sky above the Buddha and the bodhisattvas, with a pearl-studded canopy and walls that were vast and spacious.
With various kinds of extraordinary and marvelous adornments, it was evenly and beautifully decorated all around, arranged in a balanced and upright manner.
At that time, the bodhisattvas each thought in their minds:
Just as our bodies are, we vow to make our buddha lands pure and the enlightenment trees in the enlightenment sites likewise!
These bodhisattvas, as they thought in their minds, each saw a pearl-studded canopy for themselves.
Having seen this, they marveled at the unprecedented sight and went before the Buddha, saying:
It is extremely difficult to reach, O Heaven among Heavens!
The power of the precious girl's establishment is able to manifest auspicious signs for us.
The aspirations made over innumerable eons, now this Jewel Girl!
In a single moment of thought, she causes them all to appear.
The World-Honored One said:
So it is, good man!
As you have said.

The Jewel Girl, since she first gave rise to the aspiration and established her resolve, has cultivated the roots of virtue under 620 trillion buddhas, and thus has attained such sincerity and established her true vow.
For this reason, now this Jewel Girl, in accordance with her vow, dons the armor of virtue and causes the various good men to be established.
Moreover, the Jewel Girl, if she wishes to make a vow, to cause heavenly flowers to rain down and fill this trichiliocosm everywhere,
then as she speaks, it immediately rains down famous incense, pounded incense, fragrant ointments, mixed incense, clothing, and delicacies.
If she further wishes to cause banners, canopies, silk pennants to naturally adorn and pervade the sky, they are immediately accomplished as she wishes.

If they further wish to cause the natural occurrence of a water disaster in the heavens and earth, or if they wish for a fire disaster, then as they say, there will be a water disaster and a natural fire disaster;
If they further wish to eliminate and restore the water and fire disasters, as they say, they can accomplish it all.
If they wish to cause the entire assembly to naturally transform their bodies and attire to be like a wheel-turning king, they can accomplish it immediately.

For the form and attire of the Four Heavenly Kings, the appearance of Åšakra, the countenance of BrahmÄ Heaven, the appearance of the Greatly Marvelous Heaven, the appearance of bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs, they can accomplish it as they say.

Even if one wishes to transform and manifest hundreds of thousands of millions of demons, with each demon holding hundreds of swords and staves in their hands, causing these demons to firmly remain unmoving without wielding their swords and staves, all transforming into various kinds of pearl necklaces, hanging flowers, and sÄ«sa flowers, it will all be as one says.

If one further wishes to transform the vast wilderness into naturally existing food, drink, and clothing, into a great city with eighteen million households dwelling within, it will all be as one says.
All the forms in the trichiliocosm, if one wishes to transform them into the appearance of the TathÄgata, it will immediately be as one intends.
If one further wishes to cause the entire assembly to be in space, it will all be as one says.
Sons of good family!

This precious female body, I wish to make it boundless, limitless, and infinite, to the realm of the buddhas. The scriptures spoken by the buddhas, I wish to penetrate them all in the sky, to fully hear the sounds, just as the Buddha has said without any deficiency. The words of the buddhas of the ten directions, I can also proclaim them.
Then, by the power of the precious girl's vow and spiritual powers, she manifested such forms and appearances, and spoke this verse in front of the Buddha:
Using treasures as one's occupation, holding the wondrous and sacred jewels;
Expounding the noble and supreme, immeasurable virtue and conduct.
Then, one should eliminate the bonds of desire, anger, and ignorance;
And practice giving, the treasure of the seven factors of enlightenment.ğŸ”½Using the light of treasures to illuminate the myriad hidden and obscure places;
The various kinds of bright pearls shine.
The most revered and precious treasures, the finest and most excellent gems;
Now, with this precious pearl, I respectfully offer it to the Abiding One.
The pearl of blazing light, the pearl of the immaculate treasury, the radiance of the sun and moon,
The light that shines forth;
Illuminated by the Venerable One, it is all completely obscured.
Contemplating the body of the Benevolent One, there is no limit to its extent;
The blessings that are borne result in attaining the ten powers.
Standing in this land, reaching the highest realm;
Observing the sacred body, it becomes increasingly radiant.
The entire assembly, each seeing the Buddha, all think to themselves:
The Venerable One is in front of me.
From all directions, they all see the Buddha's face, the countenance of purple gold,
With an appearance that is incomparable.
Even when sitting, lying down, or walking;
If further present, in the midst of the assembly;
Whether speaking or silent, delighting in standing in meditation;
His deportment is incomparable, his wisdom is boundless.
Each pore emits radiant light,
Which can universally illuminate the entire ten directions.
His body is like a lotus flower, most supreme and vast;
Like the nature of the mind, causing the mind to be tranquil.
Always standing in sincerity, what he says is true;
As he speaks, the Honored One practices accordingly.
Understanding and discerning the principles of all dharmas;
I bow to one who is fully on the path and has crossed over to the other shore.
At that time, having praised the Buddha's virtues with these verses, Jewel Woman said to the World-Honored One:
I now wish to ask the TathÄgata about the chapters and sections of this sÅ«tra, to which they aspire;
If I am permitted, I shall then speak myself.
The Buddha told the woman:
Ask as you wish, and I shall explain it to you, causing your mind to be delighted.
At that time, when the Buddha heard this, he was delighted and joyfully said to the World-Honored One:
What is meant by bodhisattvas always being sincere?
How does the TathÄgata speak true words for the bodhisattvas?
What is meant by bodhisattvas conforming to the Dharma?
How does the TathÄgata expound the sÅ«tras for the bodhisattvas?
What is meant by bodhisattvas immediately conforming to dignified conduct?
How does the TathÄgata explain the direction of discussion for the bodhisattvas?
What is meant by bodhisattvas respectfully following the precepts?
How does the TathÄgata expound the precepts for the bodhisattvas?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
The questions asked by Jewel Woman about the true essentials of benevolence and virtuous talent are eloquent. Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider them well!
Yes, World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear them.
At that time, the Jewel Woman accepted the teaching and listened.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
Bodhisattvas always have three qualities of sincerity.
What are the three?
Never deceiving the Buddha, not deceiving oneself, and not deceiving all sentient beings.
What is meant by a bodhisattva deceiving the buddhas, deceiving oneself, and deceiving all sentient beings?

If a bodhisattva gives rise to the intention to cultivate the unsurpassed true path, but aspires to the stage of the Å›rÄvaka or pratyekabuddha, and vows to seek and delight in that intention, this is called a bodhisattva deceiving the buddhas, oneself, and all sentient beings.
What is meant by a bodhisattva not deceiving the buddhas, oneself, or sentient beings?

If a bodhisattva arouses the great aspiration for enlightenment, even if they encounter hardship and various afflictions, are disturbed by various demons, are oppressed by non-Buddhist paths, are slandered and ridiculed, are scolded in a hundred ways, beaten and harmed, and falsely accused, their mind remains tranquil, not giving rise to resentment or harboring cowardice, confusion, fear, anxiety, or hatred. Continuously upholding a single aspiration with a firm and strong mind, they do not abandon the aspiration for enlightenment through the practice of equality.
But they grasp the mind of wisdom, the mind of preciousness, and always harbor the mind of the Way, the most revered in the entire world.
Moreover, they arouse the mind for the sake of all beings, to save, protect, and liberate them.

The mind that is aroused is without equal, without analogy, not retreating, not abandoning, not in other vehicles, always establishing a single aspiration, delighting in the Buddha way, guiding and controlling the Dharma wheel, causing all beings to be able to meet face-to-face.
Manifesting in the various powers, arising and becoming manifest in this way, walking and moving, following and cultivating diligently, never destroying the teachings of others.
This is the bodhisattva not deceiving the buddhas, not deceiving himself, and also not harming or deceiving any sentient beings.
If a bodhisattva does not deceive the buddhas, does not deceive himself, and does not deceive sentient beings, this is the bodhisattva's first utmost sincerity.
He does not deceive the buddhas through four things:
Following what is firm and solid, responding with majestic giving, what he does is powerful, and he diligently makes energetic progress.
Furthermore, through four things he does not deceive himself:
His disposition is kind and harmonious, his mind is straightforward, he is without flattery or deceit, and he is also without empty boasts.
They do not deceive sentient beings in four ways:

Skillfully treating illnesses, with a compassionate and merciful mind, and adding the four kinds of kindness. This is the first sincerity of the bodhisattva, not abandoning the aspiration for enlightenment and not violating the vows of the past.
The Buddha further told Jewel Woman:
The sincerity of the bodhisattva means that the mouth is silent and protects speech, and what is said is without fault and the words are true.
Whether alone or in a large assembly, speech is always sincere, and for the sake of the country, one does not engage in divisive speech;
One does not deceive with false words for the sake of abundant treasures and wealth;
One does not engage in divisive speech for the sake of parents, relatives, and greed for wealth and stinginess.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
There are thirty-two things that are pure speech.
What are the thirty-two?
Shamelessness is one.
Creating virtue is two.
Always harboring shame is three.
Cultivating goodness equally is four.
Not engaging in inferior evil is five.
Not seeking slander is six.
Not being hasty or violent seven.
Teaching and transforming the gods eight.
Not giving rise to fear nine.
Burning the evil destinies ten.
Expounding the good refuge one.
What is commanded by the sages two.
Respectfully serving the wise three.
The inner purity four.
Skillfully cultivating the outer five.
Receiving the teachings six.
Discerning the words seven.
Speaking without arrogance eight.
Speaking softly nine.
Speaking distinctively ten.
The mouth expounding purity one.
Following the teachings two.
Being without deceit three.
Being without distress four.
Creating beloved karma five.
Internally being without loss six.
Externally also being without error seven.
Not creating evil karma eight.
Creating the ground of blessings nine.
Delighting in the Buddha's path ten.
Transmitting words with sincerity one.
Speaking and immediately gaining benefit two.
These are the thirty-two matters.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
It is called the fulfillment of sincere wishes.
Why is it so?

Generosity is for the sake of the bodhisattva path, because it is free from stinginess and greed, and this fulfills one's aspirations. If one is able to give away all one has with wisdom, seeing this afterwards is then sincerity.

Pure precepts are for the sake of the bodhisattva path, not for breaking the precepts, and this fulfills one's aspirations. If one's precepts are complete and pure, seeing this afterwards is then sincerity.

Establishing the power of patience is for the sake of the bodhisattva path, and aspiring to be free from resentment fulfills one's vow. If one is patient, this is gentleness, and seeing this afterwards is then sincerity.

Pursuing and cultivating diligence is for the sake of the bodhisattva path, and not being lazy fulfills one's aspirations. If one is able to universally practice all the roots of virtue, seeing this afterwards is then sincerity.

Establishing meditation as the bodhisattva path, not being a distracted mind, this vow is fulfilled. If one is able to embrace and cultivate single-mindedness, seeing this afterwards is then true sincerity.

Establishing wisdom as the bodhisattva path, not being a deviant wisdom, this vow is fulfilled. Understanding the wisdom of the sages, seeing this afterwards is then true sincerity.ğŸ”½The four bases of mindfulness are the bodhisattva path, not being negligent, this vow is fulfilled. The mind is then in tranquil concentration, seeing this afterwards is then true sincerity.
The four right efforts are the bodhisattva path, not giving rise to various evils, the mind is then extinguished, this vow is fulfilled. Seeing this afterwards is then true sincerity.
The four bases of supernatural powers are the bodhisattva path, not being without understanding, already able to fly, this vow is fulfilled. Seeing this afterwards is then true sincerity.

The practice of the five faculties is the bodhisattva path. The faculties are tranquil and free from confusion, fulfilling one's wishes. The faculties are serene. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.
The practice of the five powers is the bodhisattva path. Not being without power, fully endowed with the ten powers, fulfilling one's wishes. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.

The meaning of the seven factors of enlightenment is the bodhisattva path. Not being without understanding, already able to awaken, the faculties do not arise, fulfilling one's wishes. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.
The practice of the eightfold noble path is the bodhisattva path. There are no wrong paths. If one is on the noble path, fulfilling one's wishes. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.

The practice of the four kinds of kindness is the bodhisattva path. Not being without rescue, embracing all dangers and difficulties, fulfilling one's wishes. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.

Cultivating the four kinds of Brahma conduct is the bodhisattva path, not for the sake of the love, compassion, joy, and equanimity of devas and humans, but to rescue and deliver all beings, thus fulfilling one's vows. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.

The wisdom of spiritual powers, the knowledge of the three times, and the correct contemplation of tranquility are the bodhisattva path, free from all faults, and fully endowed with all practices, thus fulfilling one's vows. Seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.

Being fully endowed with all virtuous dharmas is the bodhisattva path, not for the sake of being without liberation, but to eliminate all unwholesome dharmas, thus fulfilling one's vows. If one is able to fully proclaim the Dharma of benevolence and virtue, seeing this afterwards, this is true sincerity.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
Bodhisattvas should also play, practice, and carry out the truths of the sages:
Knowing the wisdom of suffering, cutting off what is to be practiced, understanding the end of cessation, and cultivating the noble path.
What is meant by knowing suffering is to discern the five aggregates without arising.

Cutting off of habits means not habituating in the five aggregates of clinging, ultimately having no habituation in affection, and practicing the liberation gate without dwelling anywhere, not harboring any giving. That which is not harbored does not reach anywhere in the past;
if it does not reach anywhere in the past, then it does not eliminate the true Dharma;
having nothing to eliminate in all dharmas, this is cutting off of habits.
That knowledge of cessation means seeing the ultimate end of all conceptual attachments that arise.

As for that cessation, it means not harboring any attainment in birth and death, being equal in all beginnings and ends, and having no increase or decrease in any dharmas. Having already observed equality, this is the wisdom of understanding cessation.

They observe equality and are able to treat equally on the eightfold right path. Without any thoughts or wrong thoughts, they seek out afflictions and have no self. Without a self, there is nothing to accept, and then there is no birth and no creator. They are able to skillfully cultivate all dharmas. This is called the noble path.
If one has this sincere wisdom, understands everything, and penetrates all beings, then there is no internal and nothing to realize. This is the utmost sincerity of the bodhisattvas.
When the Buddha spoke this teaching on utmost sincerity, ten thousand bodhisattvas fully possessed the noble wisdom and attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
What is meant by bodhisattvas conforming to the Dharma?

Following the Dharma, contemplating the Dharma, taking the Dharma as one's nature, respecting the Dharma, practicing the Dharma, desiring the Dharma, delighting in the Dharma, abiding in the Dharma, the Dharma as the supreme flower, the Dharma as the sword and staff, wearing the armor of the Dharma, vowing to adorn oneself with the Dharma, cultivating the light of the Dharma, the lamp of the Dharma, always aspiring to the Dharma, taking the Dharma as one's mind, walking in the Dharma, discerning the scriptures, skillfully conforming to the Dharma, practicing the Dharma, the Dharma as one's bed and sleep, the Dharma as one's deportment, protecting the affairs of the Dharma, giving the Dharma, the Dharma as inexhaustible wealth, widely expounding the Dharma, the Dharma as the means of adornment, always cultivating the Dharma body, the Dharma as speech, contemplating the Dharma, and not being negligent.
In this way, following the practice of the Dharma, one fully accomplishes and conforms to the Dharma master, not doing what is contrary to the Dharma.
What is meant by 'conforming to the Dharma master'?

If one is thus sincere and truthful, dons the armor of the Buddha's teachings, protects with the Dharma, respectfully serves the noble assembly, earnestly listens to the sutras, delights in the Way, accumulates various wholesome deeds, does not abandon the ultimate truth, has a fundamentally pure disposition, is unattached, does not go against what is appropriate, sees the sages, associates with good friends, always practices respectfulness according to their teachings, is free from arrogance, praises much, roams in the Dharma assembly, listens to the sutras with utmost sincerity, aspires to seek the Dharma without being content, expounds the meaning of the Way without being lax, and has no teacher in the Dharma, thinks of repaying kindness with gratitude, and accomplishes what should be done.
Dwelling in seclusion without fear, not violating the teachings of the sages, not abandoning contentment, and following the ten wholesome [deeds].
Praising giving and encouraging the Buddha's path, upholding precepts, taking patience as strength, diligently cultivating without cowardice, peacefully entering meditation, and roaming in wisdom.

Promoting the Way and spreading skillful means, with compassion protecting many, entering into compassion and rejoicing in practice, guarding against the two things and conforming to sincerity, wherever one encounters, taking goodness as one's work, giving rise to spiritual powers and guiding the true Dharma, wherever one goes, giving the Dharma as a gift.

In the four bases of mindfulness, one does not forget one's aspirations. In the four right efforts, one cultivates equality. In the four bases of supernatural power, one attains final cessation in the present. In the clear understanding of the faculties, one cultivates the powers. In the clear understanding of the factors of enlightenment, one transcends the direct path. Entering into solitude, one observes one's practice. The wisdom of true reality, the liberation of holy wisdom, proclaims and illuminates in accordance with the Å›rÄvakas, according to their original ground, teaching the pratyekabuddhas, praising the virtues of the MahÄyÄna, then with appropriate principles, understanding dependent origination, then in emptiness, without fear, wandering in non-thought, without attachment, observing the five aggregates as illusory, viewing the four kinds as also like empty space.

Moreover, those who enter the path purify the mind and realize emptiness, cultivate the practices of the seven treasures, cultivate the six recollections, delight in the six pÄramitÄs, and attain the five eyes and the foremost wisdom.

Always guarding oneself, crossing over to the other shore, skillfully cultivating the path, and having an equal mind towards all sentient beings, one praises the merits and virtues of the innumerable buddhas.
The Buddha said to Jewel Woman:

The bodhisattva who accords with the Dharma does not speak of self, does not conceive of a person, does not conceive of a life, does not think of annihilation, does not see permanence, and does not see existence.

If one sees without separation, one does not rely on the limits, does not rely on the middle, does not follow friends, and also has no disputes, also has no disharmony, and also has no partiality, does not dwell in inversions, and is not in wrong views, transcends doubts, and removes the obstructions of the aggregates, does not go against the Dharma, is also not confused by the Dharma, does not slander the sÅ«tras, does not slight the Way, and does not extinguish the ultimate of all dharmas.
The bodhisattva who accords with the Way has a mind that embraces all dharmas and is replete with the sÅ«tras. What is said with sincerity is in accord with the Dharma!
There is nothing to be raised up. For those of different studies who speak in accord with the Dharma, deceit, difficulty, and wrong conduct are all extinguished.

In all worlds, one speaks in accord with the Dharma. The bodhisattva who accords with emptiness practices without attainment, then has no wrong thoughts and no Dharma of anger, accords with the teaching of the absence of wishes, and does not practice anywhere in the three realms, diligently and intently seeing the faults.
Bodhisattvas who accord with the Dharma have nothing that arises and nothing that ceases, and so they do not accept birth, which is by nature pure, and the meaning lies in tranquility.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:

What is called the Dharma cannot be obtained, has no written words, and is without speech or expression, without form or appearance, and has no destination. It has no teachings and nothing to teach, is apart from the mind and consciousness, and has no dust or defilements. By being apart from flaws and faults, it is far from greed and desire, has no obscurity or darkness, and nothing is accumulated. It has no 'I' or 'mine' and nothing to accept, and also nothing to grasp, apart from what is received. It has no realm and so has no distinctions.

In the worlds of the ten directions, it is unattached and thus tranquil. Abandoning bodily actions and retreating, it cannot be seen. Realizing the profound and vast, it has no thoughts or considerations, and does not restrain or control the sages and worthies. It is what the wise and intelligent ones are enlightened to and transformed by.

There is nothing to encounter and nothing not to encounter. Resting all that can be encountered is like true reality. The three times are empty, so there is no permanent submersion, no final demise, no regression, no birth, no accomplishment, no destruction, no existence, no non-existence, no accomplishment, no non-accomplishment, no activity, no seeing, no non-seeing, and no separation from seeing. Not forming characteristics and having no non-characteristics is a single characteristic.

Also, there are no characteristics and no attachments. Separated from attachments, there is nothing else. No attachment, no bondage, and nothing to be liberated from. Not mine, and not belonging to anything. Not cultivating anything, and free from all defilements. Unequaled and without equality, equal and without equality.

It is neither sincere nor false, neither happy nor sorrowful, neither diligent nor indolent, neither appropriate nor inappropriate, neither focused nor distracted, neither named nor arising, neither solid nor insubstantial, neither destroyed nor indestructible, neither adamantine nor characterized by destruction, and is true and sincere without contradiction.

It is without distinction, without distance, without form, without comparison, without location, without thought, without this or that, without difference, without inside or outside or in between, without pleasure, without reaching the other shore, without seeing or hearing, without thinking or teaching, without knowing or not knowing, without form or formless, without action or inaction, and is free from all forms. This is called the Dharma.
Such a Dharma is without sound or non-sound, without combination, without speech or expression. This is called the bodhisattva's conformity with the Dharma.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
Being fully endowed with all verbal expressions is called conforming with the Dharma.
Those who follow the Dharma have never argued with others, those who follow the Dharma do not despise
others, those who follow the Dharma do not easily belittle those who are not yet learned, and they also do not exclusively respect those who are
accomplished in learning. Those who follow the Dharma do not praise themselves or make themselves known, those who follow the Dharma

do not confuse the scriptures, those who follow the Dharma do not explain the meaning of the Dharma out of desire for offerings, those whoğŸ”½follow the Dharma never give rise to doubt for others, those who follow the Dharma never discuss the faults of others, those who follow the
Dharma do not despise the scriptures, those who follow the Dharma never obstruct the Dharma of others, those who follow the Dharma never
see or realize that there are distinctions and divisions in all dharmas, those who follow the Dharma do not see any dharmas apart from emptiness.

Those who follow the Dharma see all dharmas as not far from impermanence. Those who follow the Dharma do not see dharmas abandoning the wishless, those who follow the Dharma do not destroy the dharma realm, those who follow the Dharma do not move from the rootless, those who follow the Dharma also do not transcend the true fundamental limit, those who follow the Dharma also do not lead and control according to anger, those who follow the Dharma also do not lead and think about various consciousnesses.
Those who follow the Dharma:
Also do not lead and benefit what is relied upon, those who follow the Dharma also do not think and calculate that there is a person.
Those who follow the Dharma do not confuse the discussion of dharmas, do not violate adornment, those who follow the Dharma do not become deluded

The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
What is meant by bodhisattvas conforming to dignified conduct?

Namely, discussion means having no desire for fame, not being weak-minded, following and cultivating the treatment of all virtuous roots, accumulating good discussions with an extraordinary disposition, giving rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, and gathering empty discussions.

If one gives without expecting reward, it is a discussion of manifesting all peace and comfort, not destroying the discussion of precepts, the discussion of forbearance and non-forbearance, the discussion of transcending all the practices of vigor, and using meditation to make it a discussion of tranquility, then it is a discussion of wisdom without hesitation.

Following and cultivating kindness is a discussion of equality towards sentient beings, if one has compassion, then it is a discussion of expounding everything to sentient beings, if one has joy, it is a discussion of delighting in the Dharma, if one has protection, it is a discussion of being unmoved by suffering and pleasure.

If one gives, it is a discussion of having no teaching, happily giving birth to a discussion of causing no harm, and a discussion of accomplishment is a discussion of giving rise to the aspiration for the Dharma.
An equal discussion is a discussion of encouraging sentient beings to be devoted to the Mahayana, and using the four kinds of kindness to transform the masses.
The truth of impermanence and suffering of all things, the truth of the non-self of all dharmas.

The truth of tranquility in the midst of defilements, the truth of understanding and wisdom, the truth of adornment and guidance, the truth of the treasury of all scriptures and the benefit of the canon, the truth of transforming human life with the Dharma.
If one can understand and perceive the truth of the Dharma, the truth of inexhaustible explanation, the truth of the indestructible Dharma in distinguishing the scriptures;
If one perceives the extinction of conformity, enters the wisdom of formlessness, and encounters eloquence, explaining the truth according to the illnesses of the multitude.

If one practices giving without weariness, for the sake of fulfilling the vow of the practice of upholding precepts, for the sake of the practice of vast learning and following the essential practice, for the sake of fulfilling the marks of the practice of merit, for the sake of understanding the faculties of all beings in the practice of wisdom, for the sake of the matter of the mind in the practice of tranquility, for the sake of penetrating wisdom in the practice of observation.

The four bases of mindfulness are for controlling the mind, the four right efforts are for cultivating all meritorious dharmas, and the bases of supernatural powers are for traveling to the ten directions.

The five faculties are for not violating others and not destroying emptiness, the five powers are for not being confused by various afflictions, the seven factors of enlightenment are for understanding all dharmas, the path is for seeking without resentment towards any dharma, and the spiritual powers are for ultimately being without deficiency.
If one is like this, if one conforms to the principles of the Dharma in this way, then it is the essential principle of the ultimate Dharma.
If one accords with this principle, then one should follow the proper conduct and not act contrary to the principle.
In this way, the bodhisattva should follow the proper conduct.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
Destroying all inverted and deviant views is emptiness, and practicing emptiness is in accord with the principle for bodhisattvas.
Eliminating all thoughts, whether appropriate or inappropriate, is to be without thought. Bodhisattvas without thought then accord with appropriate principles.
Departing from all aspirations in the three realms is to be without aspirations. Bodhisattvas without aspirations then accord with appropriate principles.
Resting from all created activities is to be without activity. Bodhisattvas without activity then accord with appropriate principles.
Abandoning all births and cessations is to be unborn. Bodhisattvas without birth then accord with appropriate principles.
All arising of sensations is to be without arising. Bodhisattvas without arising then accord with appropriate principles.
Eliminating suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path is to be extinguished. Bodhisattvas of cessation then accord with appropriate principles.
All dharmas are without person or life, thus being nonexistent. Bodhisattvas without person then accord with appropriate principles.
All verbal sounds and principles are unobtainable, thus being nonexistent. Bodhisattvas without attainment then accord with appropriate principles.
The purity of all practices is sincerity, so a bodhisattva who is sincere accords with principle.
The absence of negligence in all aspects of the path is principle, so a bodhisattva who is diligent accords with principle.
All that is heard should be believed and practiced, so a bodhisattva who practices accords with principle.
All vehicles are due to the Great Vehicle, so if a bodhisattva follows the teachings of the Great Vehicle, he accords with principle.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
That which is indestructible has no various affairs, so that is principle.
That which is of one kind and one flavor is principle.ğŸ”½That which is unmoving and inexhaustible is principle.
That which is without action, unborn, and unarisen is principle.
That which has no coming and no going is principle.
That which has no birth and no cessation is principle.
There are no two things:
Not high or low, not lofty or humble, then it is principle.
Without creation and without form, then it is principle.
Without activity and without existence, then it is principle.
Without likeness, without exhortation, and without knowledge, then it is principle.

Removing the three faults and purifying the three places, equal in the three times, eternally removing the three defilements and without the three dusts, then it is principle.ğŸ”½Without dwelling and without loss, then it is principle.
Without enemies, practicing tranquility, without vexation, then it is principle.
Without solitary practice, then it is principle.
Without proclamation and without grasping, always practicing as appropriate, then it is principle.
Cutting off the past, present, and future, without flattery, then it is principle.
Also, not thinking of the right Dharma or non-Dharma, except for limited and unlimited, permanent and impermanent, with impartial wisdom one transcends and departs, then it is principle.
Regarding all the sounds that should be heard in written words, to understand that they are all originally pure and without words, then it is principle.
To understand the mind, thought, and consciousness, without speaking and yet leaving the household life, then it is principle.
Regarding the desires of lust, anger, and delusion, with or without thoughts, appropriate or not, to discern them without attachment to thoughts, then it is principle.
To be equal to all dharmas without any distinctions, not making them different, then it is principle.
Empty, without thoughts or wishes, without any creation, and also without form, then it is principle.
To understand the foremost sincere matter, without having faith, not relying on others, and not knowing the characteristics, then it is principle.
There are no edicts or teachings that do not involve the characteristics of phenomena, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of phenomena are like empty space, tranquil and still, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of non-attachment are those of non-action and non-delight, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of non-destruction are like their original non-existence, and the characteristics of true reality are without difference or distinction, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of skillful transformation are those of the aggregates being like illusions, and the characteristics of spontaneity are the meaning.
The four kinds of characteristics are those of the dharma realm, and not wandering outside the path of practice is the meaning.
The characteristics of generosity, morality, wisdom, tranquility, and skillful means are those of non-existence, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of generating sincerity and being without deception are those of all that exists being non-existent, and that is the meaning.
The characteristics of being like a vajra, solid and indestructible, and being in the world without dispute are the meaning.
The ultimate truth of what is done well is the characteristic of completeness, which is principle.
The characteristic of universally entering and completely liberating all, without obstruction or hindrance, is the characteristic of the gate of facing, which is principle.
Equality in all destinies, entering into the characteristics of all dharmas, is principle.
Equality without falsehood, seeing equality, the characteristic of non-existence, is principle.
The characteristic of giving rise to concentration, wisdom, and liberation through practice, the characteristic of liberation, knowledge, and insight, is principle.
Relying on the characteristics of the sages, the characteristic of what is known and taught, is principle.
Like the true reality, the characteristic of understanding and sending forth, equally controlling all characteristics of dharmas, is principle.
If a bodhisattva is thus complete in the cultivation of principle, and is able to speak of these various principles, then he will be able to discern all principles.
Therefore, it is called the great being bodhisattva who should seek the deportment.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
What is meant by the bodhisattva's obedience to the precepts?
The TathÄgata expounds two kinds of precepts.
What are the two?
The precept of karmic retribution and the precept of eliminating afflictions and desires.
What is meant by the precept of karmic retribution?

As for the precept of karmic retribution, it is the basis of thoughts and ideas. It should not be in accordance with the basis of ignorance, the basis of foolishness, the basis of inversion, the basis of unreality, the basis of falsehood, the basis of attachment to the body, the basis of clinging to the self, the basis of attachment to others, the basis of laziness, the basis of non-abandonment, the basis of non-return, the basis of doubt, the basis of arrogance, and the basis of difficulty in attaining wisdom. This is called the precept of karmic retribution.
What is meant by the precept of eliminating afflictions and desires?

Abiding without doubt, without thought, without a place of fault, not speaking of faults, not speaking of directions, not delighting in kings, not being dusty, without stinginess or greed, without any arising of views in the mind, with a peaceful and elegant aspiration, free from cessation, without existence, without location, without directions, without afflictions, without stinginess, and without anything to see - considering the mind, faults are also like that.

As with faults, all dharmas are also like this, without a fundamental basis and also without anything to abide in, just like the mind, which cannot be grasped, pure and clean, transcending all that exists, tranquil and simple, leading to cessation, cutting off and resting, with the troubles of birth and death - having faith in the teachings of the sages, upholding a one-pointed mind without doubt, aspiring to the same goal without any misfortune.
This is called the Vinaya for resolving dust and desires.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
What are the afflictions?
What is the Vinaya of resolving desires?
What is called dust refers to desire, anger, delusion, ignorance, affection, and the twelve links of dependent origination that are experienced. This is called dust and afflictions.
The Vinaya of resolving desires ultimately transforms all dharmas.
Why is it so?
It is because all dharmas are transformed by emptiness. There is no practice of desire, anger, or delusion;
All dharmas are transformed by the absence of characteristics. There is also no practice of indulging in afflictions;

All dharmas are transformed by the absence of wishes. There is the practice of cultivating various virtues.ğŸ”½In all practices, there is nothing to practice. Having nothing, all dharmas are transformed. By practicing nothing, all dharmas are guided and benefited.
In what is created, there is nothing to practice. All dharmas depend on causes and conditions. In all views, there is nothing to cultivate.
If one can understand the twelve links of dependent origination and the equality of all dharmas, then in all afflictions there will be no desires, and the basis will be extinguished.
What is called emptiness is the emptiness of the mundane and the Way.
By this emptiness, all afflictions and desires are also empty.
If one can equate emptiness with the Way, this is the definitive desire discipline.
It is said that the discipline of the sutras is called discipline when it opens and transforms itself.
One who can know how to transform one's own body will be able to understand the discipline of transforming desires.
What is meant by the discipline of transforming one's own body?

Those who are able to discriminate between self and non-self, who know the body is naturally so, who understand their own simplicity and the truth of their own reality, who understand their own body without anger or resentment, who discriminate the emptiness of the body and their own non-existence, who understand their own rootlessness and their own non-attainment, who discriminate their own body as unmoving, who discriminate their own body as incomparable, who understand their own non-arising and non-origination, those who understand the self in this way understand afflictions, which also have no root!
Just as there is no self but the thought of self is inverted;
if it were so, then the self would have no afflictions but the thought of afflictions would arise, which is inverted.
Also, just as the self is originally pure and without a body, so too are desires originally pure and without afflictions.
Those who understand such contemplation will decisively regulate desires.
They do not transform past desires, nor do they have future or present desires.
Why is it so?
Because one does not cultivate practices and does not think of desires and defilements again.
One who has nothing to think of in one's own body has no past, no future, and no present.
Moreover, the mind has no form, so there is no inside or outside, and nothing to attain. Desires and defilements are also like this, having no form, no inside or outside, and nothing to attain.
Having nothing to attain means having no anger or resentment, no disputes or eliminations, no creations or non-creations, no actions and no non-actions.

All desires and defilements that roam here, in regard to desires and defilements, discern kindness and love, but have no existence and are not apart from existence. This is called the discipline of resolving desires and defilements.
The Buddha told Jewel Woman:
If a bodhisattva understands and awakens to this, and transforms the discipline of desires, he will be able to teach and guide the desires and defilements of the masses and expound the Dharma!
This is called respectfully following the precepts.

The Buddha spoke this true and correct teaching of the Dharma, and in accordance with principle respectfully followed the precepts. Ten thousand bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The precious girl joyfully gave rise to a sense of urgency and a wholesome mind. She then addressed the Buddha, saying:
Never before has there been such, TathÄgata!
You have excellently spoken this true and correct Dharma, praising and singing the principles of the precepts.
If a bodhisattva respectfully practices in this way, it will be foremost, without any disputes. He will then be able to eliminate the disputes of sentient beings and follow the scriptures.
